values:
My website is now online and active.  A huge thanks to Evan and Ryan for getting the blog build (Evan) and setting it up on my site (Ryan).  I am so happy.  I will no longer use Live Journal and will use my new site and news program.  You can reach my site at:
Tammy's World

Yesterday, Dad's work had a company picnic at African Lion Safari, located about an hour and a half outside Toronto.  The picnic part of it wasn't bad.  I didn't really meet that many people because everyone was busy setting up or cooking or whatnot.  The zoo brought in an elephant to play tug-o-war with.  The elephant was 8,900 pounds and playing tug-o-war with it was pointless but fun.  Every time the elephant pulled, piles of people went flying.  Due to it's sheer strength and the type of rope they used, as soon as it started hurting my hands, I let go which turned out to be each time that my mother-in-law took a picture.  LOL. My favorite part was when we went through the baboon area.  In this park you can either drive your own vehicle through the zoo or take the bus.  You literally get right up to the animals and they often come right up to your vehicles.  In the baboon area, there are literally around 50 or so baboons and they come right up and hop onto your vehicles.  The baboons are highly curious and quite destructive creatures.  We watched them rip off windshield seals, decorative stripping on the side of cars, radio antennas and much more from vehicles.  They ride your vehicles the entire way through their area which is quite big.  I would have happily rode around over and over in that area all day; it was so much fun.  The other zone where curious animals come up to your vehicles was the zone with the zebras and giraffes, like the baboons, they walk right up to your vehicle and check you out while blocking traffic at the same time.  We had a lot of fun but all that time in the sun sapped our energy and gave most of us migraines.  We were very happy to finally get home.  Unfortunately, there was no time for sleep to get rid of those migraines.  It was time to head to Jack Astor's for dinner.  I have to say we were disappointed.  They changed their menu again and got pretty cheap.  You used to get an order of Garlic Pan Bread (which is awesome stuff) with your entree but now they charge you for it.  They reduced the portions of the meals and raised the prices.  I can't say that we will be returning to this place anymore.    I ordered the Three Peppercorn Grilled Chicken Rigatoni, as usual, which is rigatoni pasta tossed with fresh garlic and peppercorn sauce, topped with herb-grilled chicken and bacon.  It is really good but it is supposed to be drenched in the sauce and they put so little on it that most of the pasta didn't have any sauce on it despite my efforts to spread what little sauce there was. After our disappointing dinner, we headed to Blockbuster and rented Cold Mountain and Underworld.  We saw Cold Mountain last night.  I thought it was an ok drama.  I didn't think that it earned the awards that it received nor the nominations but it wasn't a bad movie just not all that great.  Ryan and Dad hated it. By the time the movie ended, our already exhausted bodies were completely wiped out and we headed to bed and passed out.

I have been a faithful user of IE browsers since the early versions but I have to admit, I installed the new Mozilla Firefox 0.9 and WOW, it is nice.  One of my favorite features is the tabs.  Instead of opening a new browser window all the time, I can tell it to open a new tab.  It totally cuts down on all the quickbar clutter at the bottom of my screen and keeps things organized.  I can even rearrange the tabs to move them into any order that I desire.  Further, it will remember what tabs are open so if I crash or want to get back to that site(s), I can do so easily. It has over a hundred extentions (mini-applications) within it to allow for extended features such as a built in calculator and calendar.  For those who like to save their passwords for various sites in their browser, you can easily and quickly see which sites have your password saved in the options screen.  No, it won't tell you what the passwords are, but it will show you what site(s) it has one saved for.  It also tracks your download history, has a built in pop-up blocker, automatically keeps itself updated with it's "Smart Update" feature. This browser has all the options that you wished IE or Netscape had and more that you could never dream possible.  The best part is that it asks you in the installation what your old browser program was and can import all your bookmarks, history, cookies, etc. I would defiantely recommend it to all my friends.

Last night, Ryan, Amanda, Geordan and I watched 50 First Dates.  What a great movie.  When I wasn't laughing so hard that I thought I might tinkle in my panties, I was crying from the touching scenes.  We really love that movie.  Well... Geordan would have liked it if he hadn't fallen asleep within the first 10 minutes.  Poor guy has been working himself to death.  I would definately recommend watching it if you hadn't.  

Honestly, I thought it would turn out to be as stupid as "Along Came Polly" but it really impressed me.  I didn't expect it to be so good and we have happily burned a copy of it for future viewing.

This week, I also cut my hair (back to shoulder length) and dyed it, well... temporarily dyed it.  I used a temp dye that only lasts about a month just to see if I would like the color.  It is a very deep auburn color.  While the color looks nice, I was hoping for something a little lighter.  This color came out far, far darker than my natural color.  My hair is normally a light to medium brown with gold and red natural highlights.  Now it is a very, very dark brown with tons of red highlights but you don't see the red except in the sunlight so it kinda defeats the purpose.  Ryan and Amanda like it but I am not a fan.  Thank goodness I chose the temporary dye.  LOL.  I haven't dyed my hair since just before I joined the Air Force in 1991.  What I have decided is that I simply like my natural hair color.  It suits me.

That's about everything going on in my life right now.  Have fun everyone.

Since I am in Canada now, I figured it is only right that I celebrate their holidays.  In honor of Canada Day, here are some Canadian things for everyone. The Canadian Anthem O Canada! Our home and native land! True patriot love in all thy sons* command. With glowing hearts we see thee rise, The True North strong and free! From far and wide, O Canada, we stand on guard for thee. God keep our land glorious and free! O Canada, we stand on guard for thee. O Canada, we stand on guard for thee. Facts: On July 1, 2004 Canada will celebrate it's 137th year since Confederation. Before 1982 Canada Day had been known as Dominion Day, First of July, Confederation Day, and July the First. Canada Day celebrates the events that occurred on July 1, 1867, when the British North America Act created the Canadian federal government. The BNA Act proclaimed "one Dominion under the name of Canada," hence the original title of the holiday, "Dominion Day." Dominion Day was officially renamed "Canada Day" by an Act of Parliament on October 27, 1982. This change reflected the policy of successive governments to down play Canada's colonial origins. Canada's national celebration is always observed on July 1, unless that date falls on a Sunday, in which case it is observed the following day. On June 22, 1980, Canada officially adopted "O Canada" as their National Anthem So there you go, there are a few things about Canada and their Independence.  Enjoy.

We have finally received photos of Saturn's moon named Phoebe.  Phoebe's estimated age is approximately 4.5 billion years and it is certainly showing its age as it is fairly beaten up. Phoebe was visited Friday by the Cassini spacecraft. The successful flyby exposed the small world in amazing detail.  This flyby is part of a 53 flyby mission of seven moons in the Saturnian system. Scientists have suspected Phoebe is instead an object captured from the Kuiper Belt, a more distant region of icy bodies beyond Neptune. There were already clues: Phoebe is oddly dark for a moon and it orbits backward compared to the rotation of Saturn and the paths of the planet's larger moons. Some of the bright areas on the small moon may be material from below -- possibly water ice -- that's been exposed by impacts.  It is too early to tell.

This weekend we headed up to the lake.  All I can say is "Wow!"  What an amazing weekend.

Friday:  Ryan, Dad and I head up to meet the delivery guy.  He was bringing our new trailer, fresh from the factory.  So we arrive about an hour before when the trailer was to arrive, only to see that there are tree's down on our property.  Let me explain a little (for those who are too lazy to scroll back), on Easter, we received a message that a tree had fallen on our travel trailer.  The tree totaled the trailer and we (mom and dad) were forced to buy a new one or stop going up north every weekend.  They didn't want to give up their special weekends so they used the insurance money to make a hefty down payment on a new 2004 factory-made and customized 33ft. travel trailer.  Due to the tree falling on our trailer, the manager of the community cut down a bunch of trees that were threatening to fall on other trailers.  So we arrive and a bunch of trees had been cut down on the ones that were cut down in our area were strewn through our lot in pieces.  We had no choice but to immediately move all of it before the guy bringing the trailer showed up.  We no sooner finish and they guy shows up.

Within 30 minutes, our new trailer was positioned, anchors and jacks in place and we were taking a tour of our new weekend getaway.  We noticed a few problems right away, there was improper stitching on the awning so we had to call to have it replaced, there were holes in the shower curtain, and there were not stoppers for the bathroom sink and shower/tub.  Dad called the dealership and they said they would re-order the awning and they should be able to install it next week, as well as bring the stoppers and a new shower curtain.

Ryan, Dad and I spent the rest of the day (from 10am to 6pm) cleaning all the old stuff and bringing it back into the trailer.  WOW, that was a long day.  Then we waited while Mom, Amanda and Jessica showed up.  Jessica ended up coming with Grannie, Papa and Aunt Barbara.  A couple hours later (around 11:30pm) mom and Amanda showed up.  Amanda had a softball game otherwise they would have arrived much sooner.  We had a bunch of stuff loaded into the van so we brought in the essentials and then started settling down for the night.

Let me interject some fun things.  Earlier in the day, I was sitting on the deck and Ryan and I saw several silk worms.  This was the first time I had ever seen silk worms.  They look like catapillers.  They hand down from a silk stand (web like thing) then crawl back up their silk while wadding it into a ball.  It was actually really fun to watch.  Then a little later, an adorable chipmunk came right up to me looking for some peanuts; unfortunately, I didn't have any.  He was so adorable.  I had never seen a chipmunk before either.

Just before heading to bed, we (Amanda, Ryan and I) were walking to the restrooms when Ryan told us to look up.  There were soooo many stars out and for the first time (yes a lot of firsts this weekend), I was able to see the Milky Way.  Later in the summer, Ryan says I should be able to see the Northern Lights.

Saturday:  Bright and early at 8:30am, I woke to hear mom re-arranging the dishes.  Dad and I put them in the wrong spot.  Figures!  She was making quite a racket but somehow I managed to get another hour's sleep (being awakened by a lot of noise off and on) before dad finally told us to get our bums out of bed to eat breakfast.  

After a hearty breakfast of bacon, eggs, toast and soda bread, dad, Ryan and a bunch of guys from the community helped us move our deck over and re level it.  The new trailer is a little larger and has it's awning poles in a different location so we had to move the deck so that when the awning is replaced, we can put up the add-a-room.

After the deck was moved, Amanda, Ryan and I headed into town to buy me a swimsuit.  Talk about stress!  I hate swimsuits, they show off every single flaw that we have.  Ryan wanted me to get a 2-piece, I wanted a one piece.  After much debate, I got a 2-piece to make my husband happy.  I just wish it wasn't so um.... small.

We got back to the trailer, changed into our suits and spent several fun hours in the lake.  We had planned to take out the boat to the middle of the lake to swim but after about 45 minutes, we had to accept that the boat wasn't going to start. *pooh*  So we headed to the beach instead.  Unfortunately, the water is still pretty cold so by the time we were finished, I was freezing.  I must have reduced my core temperature because I was cold for many hours afterwards but it was worth it.  We had such a great time.  Even Jessica was having fun in the water with us.  I don't think I've seen her laugh so much in an entire week let alone a few hours!

After the swim, we headed to town for dinner, then came back to start a campfire.  Apparently, our campfires are "the" hangout spot.  One-by-one and two-by-two, people would show up with beer, snacks and chairs in their hands and the circle around the fire grew bigger and bigger.  We sat around the fire with the neighbors for hours until it was time to head to bed.  Amanda, Ryan and I stayed up to play some cards (I swear Ryan cheats) before we also turned in.

Sunday:  What a sad morning.  We were all disappointed that the weekend was coming to a close.  Further, our perfect weekend weather had turned dark as the skies opening up to rain down upon us.  Apparently, Mother Nature was sad as well.  After a fantastic breakfast of French toast, dad got a tow for the boat from a neighbor to take the boat to the shop to get checked out and we sat around playing cards for a little bit before giving up and packing to come home.  Amanda, Ryan and I left around lunch time, stopped at the dairy on the way home (a tradition) before making it home.  I headed straight up to bed to catch a nap, I was so tired.

All in all, it was an amazing weekend that I didn't want to end.  I can't wait until next weekend.

I am currently working on rebuilding my website; once complete, I will stop using Live Journal and utilize my own blog system.  I will keep you updated and post the web address when it is ready to come online.

I know!  I haven't posted in a while.  Not too much has been happening.  We went up north a couple weekends ago and that was a disaster but that's about it.  Feeling a little burned out on Everquest, mainly because I live the life of a cleric and that means 5000 private messages in game for rez calls, heals, buffs, groups, etc.  Now that my character is in her mid 50's, the messages happen more and more.  It gets to the point that I spend most of my time answering messages than playing.  I finally put myself into roleplaying mode only for the purpose of hiding my class and level from people to reduce the number of tells that I get.  It doesn't eliminate all of them, but it helps.

That's all that has been going on.  Sorry to bore you.
The soil has been turned and is ready for planting.  I can't wait.  There are so many different flowers that I can have here.  Such as... Bleeding Hearts! I can't wait.

I'm afraid I have some disappointing news.  Blue Bunny has been found.  To the munch who found Blue Bunny and returned him safely home, I hope you are tormented with nightmares of Blue Bunnies eating you while you sleep.  

To make matters worse, a "new" blankie has been given as a replacement for Jessica's old one which, if you read the last post, was wonderfully tossed in the trash thanks to a kind-minded maid who had our best interests at heart.  My mother-in-law, decided that Jessica (at 12 years old) simply couldn't get over the tragedy of her lost blankie so she cut out another scrap from the original blankie for Jessica to use.  Argh!!!!  The really sad part about it is that Jessica was just about over the loss and was dealing with it just fine until mom stepped in and gave her a new one.  *rolls eyes*  Now we get to be tortured with this thing for another couple years and every time it is misplaced, my husband will be the natural target even when he won't go near the nasty thing. Bleh!

The family just arrived home from their vacation to Myrtle Beach.  They came home a day early due to a motorcycle convention which made it impossible for them to sleep.  They arrived tan and cold; they got too used to the warm temperatures at the beach.

The girls made stuffed animals at a factory, visited an aquarium and many more things that took up their time.  They had a fabulous vacation.  They even came home bearing gifts.  I received two t-shirts, a shell (from Jessica), and a carton of American cigarettes (they are cheaper in the states and taste better, lol).  Ryan got a shot glass, two t-shirts, a shell and a pair of tear-away pants.

One of the first announcements they made upon arriving home was a good one.  It appears that the maid threw away Jessica's blankie while cleaning the room one day.  LOL.  This "blankie" as she calls it was really just a small scrap of what was once a blanket.  It was about 4 inches long and maybe half an inch wide and was knotted up to hold it together.  The thing was rank and disgusting.  We've been trying to convince her to get rid of it; she's twelve and doesn't need a security blanket anymore.  One item down, two more to go.  Now if we can get her to stop sucking her finger, and stop carrying around "Blue Bunny" all will be well.

Unfortunately, we were unable to kill the fish, as per mom's "suggestion".  LOL.  She said "I wouldn't be sad if the fish was to possibly die while we are gone."  and then added, "Be sure to throw it away, tank and all, into the trash."  Sadly, the fish lived.  It is a hearty little fish.  Plus, when grandma came over each morning to feed the dog and cat, she also fed the fish.

On a separate note, springtime in Toronto is quite lovely.  There are so many beautiful flowers popping up in everyone's yards and dandelions growing wild in everyone's grass.  We have a gorgeous white flowered tree in the complex that makes me smile every time I see it.  Grandma's cherry blossom is looking gorgeous along with all her other plants that I have no idea what they are because we didn't have them in Phoenix.  I wouldn't want to be anywhere else, I love it here in Toronto and I love being with my husband.

Easter was a fantastic family day.  We woke in the morning to find Easter baskets full of treats for us to enjoy.  We also got one big present each.  Ryan and Amanda got new shoes.  Jessica received a new bedding set that she's been wanting and I got a new outfit (jeans, which I haven't owned any in over 8 years and a t-shirt that I will wear once it warms up).  The "Easter Bunny" left clues for Amanda (19) and Jessica (12) to find their Easter treats.  That was pretty cute, actually.  I think that is a tradition that Ryan and I will keep going when we have children.

After all the treats were found and our new items modeled, ohh'd and ahh'd over, my father-in-law made us a nice Easter breakfast.  Then we hung out at home until 3pm when we headed to the grandparents.  We enjoyed a nice game of Ramoley (sp?) and had a lovely Easter turkey dinner.

Unfortunately, not long after dinner as we were preparing to go home, my father-in-law received a bad telephone call.  It appears that a tree has fallen onto our trailer up in Haliburton and it needs to be looked at as quickly as possible. Dad stressed about it all night and him and mom headed up to check it out first thing this morning.

While I was sleeeping (Ryan kept me up all night the eve of Easter), I heard a knock at the door and the dog barking like she was on fire.  Let me preface this by saying that my depth perception really sucks ever since I cut my eye open with a rock when I was 13.  So I rush to answer the door, afraid of missing a possible package.  I am really bad about sleeping through deliveries.  Anyway, I was rushing to answer the door and misjudged the very first step on the stairs and fell all the way down them.  I hurt pretty much everything on the way down but the biggest thing I hurt (no pun intended) was my bum.  Go ahead and laugh but my left cheek is swollen from a HUGE lump and rug burn.  It took like an hour before I could even attempt to sit down and even then I was in a lot of pain.  I'm walking a bit better now and I can even sit (albiet with a lot of pain).  It is getting better as time moves along but oy!  the pain is terrible.  If it had happened to anyone else, I probably would have laughed but after having to deal with it myself, well... I doubt I'll laugh in the future because I KNOW how much it hurts.

See, with my depth perception problem, I have a hard time with stairs.  It was never a big deal because I always lived in a single story home but now I live in a townhouse with two floors and a basement.  I'm constantly misjudging the stairs but usually it is the last couple steps going down or the first couple steps going up.  This is the first time I've fallen from top to bottom and hopefully the last.

I was really lucky because I was trying to find Ryan's pager number to let him know what happened and all of a sudden he calls.  We were apparently on the same wavelength but then we already knew that; we are soulmates.  So he rushed home from work (seriously, I was in a lot of pain) and took care of me.  I love him so much.  


To sum everything up:

Easter was great

The tree that cut through the trailer really sucks

My bum really freaking hurts.

Easter, trees and bums.  Oh my!

In an article on MSNBC, a Canadian judge ruled that peer-to-peer file swapping/sharing is legal in Canada and does not infringe upon copyrights.  Here is the article.  This is excellent news for Canadians who wish to download MP3's.  The following is excerpts from the article...
Sharing copyrighted works on peer-to-peer networks is legal in Canada, a federal judge ruled on Wednesday, handing the record industry a sharp setback in its international fight against file swappers.
In a far-ranging decision, the court further found that both downloading music and putting it in a shared folder available to other people online appeared to be legal in Canada
Canada's debate over file-swapping flared last December, when the country's Copyright Board, which regulates intellectual property issues, ruled that downloading songs from a peer-to-peer network for personal use -- but not necessarily uploading -- appeared to be legal. The regulators cited a long-standing rule in Canada, in which most copying for personal use was allowed. To repay artists and record labels for revenues lost by this activity, the government imposes a fee on blank tapes, CDs and even hard-disk-based MP3 players such as Apple's iPod, and distributes those revenues to copyright holders.
With respect to downloading, the judge accepted the Copyright Board's early decision almost without comment. But he went further, citing a recent Supreme Court decision to say that making music available online also appeared to be legal. In that recent case, the Supreme Court ruled that libraries were not "authorizing" copyright infringement simply by putting photocopy machines near books. The libraries were justified in assuming that their customers were using the copiers in a legal manner, the high court ruled. Finckenstein said the same rationale should apply to peer-to-peer users. "The mere fact of placing a copy on a shared directory in a computer where that copy can be accessed via a P2P service does not amount to distribution," Judge Konrad von Finckenstein wrote. "Before it constitutes distribution, there must be a positive act by the owner of the shared directory, such as sending out the copies or advertising that they are available for copying." Ottawa's Geist said this appeared to make uploading itself legal as well, since a peer-to-peer user -- like a library -- would be entitled to assume that the person on the other side of the connection was acting legally, since downloading was also legal in Canada.

Well, not officially but they are coming Tuesday after they get off work to pick it up.  My car, a 1998 Mazda Protege LX, had to be sold because we can't bring it to Canada.  We can't afford the payments.  Technically, the car is paid off at least to the bank but my mom, as an incentive to get me to move back to Arizona from Kansas, paid off the car and put the remaining 13 months of car payments onto her credit card.  Mainly, she got pissed at my bank because they weren't honoring the financial power of attorney that I gave her so to solve the problem, she paid the car off.  Anyway, I've been paying the payments to my mother instead of to the bank.  However, the payments are higher to us because we have to convert Canadian dollars to American dollars.  So a $220/mo payment is almost $300 Canadian each month.  Ryan and I can't afford that right now so we had to sell the car.

The lady who is buying the car fell in love with my car instantly.  She wanted to buy it today but the banks are closed and they are unable to get a cashier's check today so they are coming back on Tuesday to get it.  They even asked if they can keep the cowboy hat that hangs from my rear view mirror.  (It was an old air freshener that I bought when my car was 2 days old.  I wasn't able to find another one like it so I kept the little hat in my car because it matched the interior and it was cute)  Anyway, we are really happy about selling my car and we got what I asked for.  I will still owe my mom a little bit of money because she didn't just close my car loan account but my credit card as well, however, the amount is nominal and once I get my residency here in Canada and start working, I'll be able to pay that off in no time at all.  It's only like $1500 USD that I will still owe her.  No biggie.

Anyway, I'm happy and sad about the sale of the car.  Happy that we won't have to keep paying on it but sad that I am losing the only thing I owned that was worth anything. I bought the car with only 11 miles on it.  It was brand new and it was a great car that never gave me a lick of trouble.  It served me well and I will miss it.  Heck, I've missed having my car since I came to Canada.  I miss being able to just hop in my car and go where I want, when I want.  I can't do that here.  I can't drive any of the family cars because I'm not on the insurance and I don't have a Canadian license so I can't get on the insurance, plus, I doubt we can afford to put me on the policy.  We pay something like $2200 a year for Ryan to be on the policy and that kills us enough.

Someday, I will get another car and everything will be fine but for now, I am stuck without a car.  I have a feeling that when the time comes, I will have to learn the public transit system here.

The other day, Ryan and I had a fabulous day together.  Ryan worked in the morning for a couple hours but was home within an hour of me waking up.  We dedicated the entire day to spending time together; just us.  We hung out in our basement living room for a while, then headed upstairs to watch last week's episode of Average Joe: Adam Returns.  We ordered a pizza for lunch, then had some special private time that I'm not going to talk about in a journal.  An hour after that, we decided to take a nap.  We took a four-hour nap wrapped in each others arms.  

When we woke from our nap it was pretty late, so we headed out and got dinner and picked up some rental movies.  We ate dinner, then watched movies cuddled up in one another's arms until 4am.  We even came up with plans to further enhance our basement living room.  We are going to buy a sheet and some rolled batting and I'm going to fold the sheet in half, fill it with batting and make a little cushion for the floor so that when we watch movies, our bums don't get numb. 

Overall, while it was an inexpensive night spent mostly at home, we had the best time.  It was absolutely perfect and best of all, we got some much needed quality time together.  Lately, it has felt as though we were sharing our time with the family.  Whether it was Ryan, Jessie and I heading out to go Geocaching, or spending time with the grandparents, or the family, it felt as though we had no time for just us.  So we dedicated that day together and it was heaven.

I love being with my husband and I can't wait until we can do this again.
Today is the first day of Spring and, as if to scoff in the face of this reality, the weather has decided that it would SNOW today; a nice slushy wet snow.  Welcome Springtime.

Today, Ryan, Jessica (Ryan's youngest sister) and I went Geocaching.  For those who have never heard of it, Geocaching is basically hiding special items in locations for other Geocacher's to find, then they take them and put them in another Geocaching site somewhere else.  Each cache has a story behind it.  Some caches are meant to travel the world, some to travel to specific locations, some are just virtual caches which you just find landmarks and answer the questions and learn a little about the location. Today we went to a park here in Toronto, with our caching items in hand, we used the GPS system to get us to the location of the caches.  Then we hunted around FOREVER trying to actually FIND the cache, even decoded the clues for better luck in finding them.  The first location was hidden in the trunk of a live tree.  The trunk had a whole in it and the waterproof box was way up inside the the trunk of the tree.  This was the first location and the one we spent the most time on because we had never done it before and so we had no clue where to start looking.  We succeeded though and had a great time.  We were exhausted by the end of the first but after finding it, we caught a second wind and headed on to the second. The second was a virtual cache.  We pretty much figured out where it was but the GPS kept saying that while we were moving in the right direction, we were getting further and further from it.  After walking what had to be several miles, we finally gave up and decided that the virtual wouldn't be nearly as fun. The third and final cache was difficult.  While the clues pretty much led us right to it (since the GPS was being stupid due to all the trees in the park) but the hard part was actually getting to it.  The cache was hidden on the side of a somewhat steep and VERY slippery hill.  The last cache had been there for several years and had TONS and TONS of visitors.  Looking through the log book that you sign when you visit every cache, it appears that everyone loved the challenge of finding the location and had a grand time with it.  For the final one, we actually accidentally left our cache items in the car (only on this last one) so we just looked but took nothing and left nothing. Overall, the experience was amazing.  We had a grand time and spent some quality time with Jessica.  She loved it and can't wait for our next Geocaching trip.  Now that Sully the Bear (Jessie's first Geocaching item) has been placed, she is eager to see it's progress as it travels throughout Canada.  Sully is a Canada Mini-beanie baby bear.  Sully has two siblings, an American beanie bear that hopes to travel throughout the United States in as many places as possible before returning home to Canada.  Pineapple Bear, World Explorer is a beanie with a pineapple costume on that hopes to travel all over the world before returning to Toronto.  What a great family thing to do!

Do you like jigsaw puzzles?  If so, here is a cool site, you can upload photos or use the ones already on the site.  You can adjust settings from 6 pieces to 240 pieces, from classic puzzle shapes to strange and unusual shapes to test your mind.  Jig Zone, Check it out.

Over the weekend we watched a few movies.  I'm not going to tell you about the movies, the plots and such.  I'm just giving my opinions on them.  I don't want to ruin them for anyone if they hadn't seen it.  What I have done instead is posted the descriptions from Yahoo

The first was Mona Lisa's Smile.  This movie wasn't bad.  I have to say I enjoyed it;  however, it is not something I would want to watch again for a while.  It is one of those movies that I'd watch maybe once a year or so.  I liked the cast line up:  Julia Roberts, Julia Stiles and Kirsten Dunst.  I heard a lot of mixed reviews from people on this movie and I have to say, you either like it or hate it.  Ryan didn't like it but Amanda, my mother-in-law and I did.

Yahoo Movie Description: 1953 America was a time ripe for change for women and when Katherine Ann Willis (Julia Roberts) arrives to teach Art History at Wellesley College, she finds the institution drowning in outdated mores. While the nation struggles with the fears that accompany a shifting political culture, the powers that be at Wellesley seem to want to re-corset the women who had been the backbone of the World War II workforce just a few years earlier. A passionate educator, Katherine takes on the establishment and in doing so, deeply affects her students who in turn lead her to alter the course of her life forever. 

The other movie we rented was an awesome one; Radio.  Talk about an amazing movie.  If you haven't seen this movie, rent it because it is great.  This is a true story type movie.  When I was in Arizona, we went for years without television and didn't get our television back until a few days before Ryan and I were married so I had no clue that this movie was even out.  Over Christmas, I remembered seeing a preview for it at the theater that said it was coming out on video soon.  Ryan and I both looked at each other and said that we both wanted to see it.  Seriously, if you see this movie in the video store, you should rent it.

Yahoo Movie Description: Radio tells the story of Football coach Harold Jones (Ed Harris),who befriends mentally challenged student Radio (Gooding), at T. L. Hanna High School in Anderson, South Carolina. Initially, Radio is shy and tormented by the students and townspeople, but as his friendship with Jones extends over several decades, he finds the strength within to changes perceptions and challenge prejudices, eventually transforming the entire community.

Geez, talk about frustrating!  For the past few weeks, it snows then melts, then snows, then melts.  One day it is cold and snowing, then next day it is slightly warmer and the snow melts.  Or other days, it snows in the morning and melts in the afternoon then snows again in the evening.  I wish it would make up its mind.  Either it is cold and snowing or it is warm and beautiful.  It needs to pick one and stick with it!  LOL.Today, it is freezing and snowing.  Grrr...  You never know how to dress or which jacket to wear.  I own three jackets.  A heavy winter jacket, a medium spring time jacket and a wind breaker.  In the past couple weeks, I've worn one of each because the weather can't make up its mind.  Technically, it is still winter until around the 20th so I guess I can't complain about the cold, winter is supposed to be cold.  I'm simply getting sick of the snow.  The novelty of it has worn off. :P

To my dear friends whom have recently been introduced to this page... this is just temporary.  I'm waiting on a friend to make me a graphic for my web page and for my husband to be nice *bats eyelashes* and creates me a clone of his site.  I really like his set up and want a version for myself.  If any of my friends use LJ, I would be happy to add you to my friend's list.  Just email me and I'll get that set up.

P.S.  Hi Beans!!!!!  I miss ya!

Bleh, don't you just hate migraines?  I've been plagued with them lately and it is driving me nuts.  I'm beginning to wonder if there is something in the air in the basement that is causing them.  Ryan thought they might be caused by having the lights out and using the computers with the lights off but I was off the computer all day and had the lights on and I still got a whopper of a migraine.  Luckily, I took a long nap and was able to get rid of most of it.  (btw, we have the lights out because my monitor is really old and dying and I can't see the screen without the lights off when I play Everquest)

So I'm back to my thoughts that there is something in the air; some smell or chemical that is causing them.  It's not like I am stressing about anything.  I have nothing to stress about; my life is fabulous.  Bleh, I wish they'd just go away and leave me alone!

People are funny things.  They talk in double-talk.  They say one thing and mean another.  Why can't people just say what they want to say and leave it at that?

I've been told that I live in the past.  I've come to realize that most people do.  People make judgments on things that have happened to you, to them, and to others in the past and they relive them every time an argument ensues.  Case in point, a "discussion" happened tonight and a lot of things were brought up from the past that had little or no bearing on the "discussion" at hand.  This isn't the first time something like this has happened.  Thinking back onto discussions that I've had with people throughout my life, I realize that everyone lives in the past; or at least brings the past to the present whenever it suits them.  Such is the way with humans and their thought processes.

Ryan, the family and I went to the trailer show here in Toronto.  I thought it would be pretty lame but I actually had a lot of fun.  They had all kinds of trailers from buses to RV's to pop-up trailers.  Ryan and I found a nice little pop-up trailer that would be perfect for up north.  We want to get something simple and not expensive but would afford us some privacy when we go up north each weekend in the summer.  

Ryan's family has a place up in cottage country right on the lake that they have some travel trailers on.  They go up every weekend starting in late spring and on through till October.  His parents travel trailer is small though and won't easily accommodate another person but for this year, that is what it will have to do.  The pop-up that Ryan and I want to get is $8500 Canadian and we can't afford it this year but next year we are planning to get it.  It will actually sleep about 6 people or so, even though it will only be used for us.  It has a sink, stove, heater, etc. It is actually quite nice and fairly roomy.  The reason we like the pop-up so much is because it will easily attach to one of our vehicles and we can take it anywhere.  We hope to be able to travel a bit, now and then, and this would be perfect for that and still be able to accommodate us when we decide to have children.

Grandma, Papa and Aunt Barbara bought a new travel trailer.  It's very, very nice.  They won't get it until the boat is paid off in July but it will be a great place to hang out when the weather turns bad.  I suspect most of our time will be spent outside when the weather is good.  It has a lot of room as it extends  out on the sides when parked.  Plenty of room for 9 people to hang out in but not much room to spare. 

All-in-all, while an exhausting day, it was a lot of fun.  Ryan and I got to dream a little and the grandparents were able to purchase a new trailer for up north.

When people get married, they inherit traditions for each side of the family.  For some, it's simply holiday traditions.  For other families, it is a slew of traditions that can rattle your brains.

When I married my husband, I married into a family with so many traditions they could fill an epic novel.  Not only are there numerous holiday traditions, but there are other traditions that tend to pop up from time to time.  There is the tradition of "no chores" ,so to speak, on each person's birthdays.  There is the tradition of eating in certain locations on specific days, i.e. Wednesdays is mall eating day, every other Sunday is dinner at the grandparents, once a month the family comes here to eat, etc.  Then there is the latest tradition that I was just apprised of.  This is the tradition of making Oscar picks and betting on them.  

I don't know about you, but I do NOT like betting.  I don't even enjoy going to casinos.  This family bets on everything.  Money exchanges faster in this household than in the NYSE.  So, anyway, my mother-in-law informed me moments ago that betting on the Oscars is mandatory.  Now, let me give a little back information.  When I lived in Arizona, we had no television reception for 2 years.  I never knew what movies were happening because attending movies at theaters is too hard on my knees.  I rarely rented movies because I rarely could afford it.  In all essence, I didn't watch anything.  I simply played on my computer and that was it.  So, back to today, having seen only a handful of movies since moving to Canada, I simply don't know who is up for what awards and what 90% of the movies listed even are about.  

Ahhh, traditions.  Every family has them. Some more than others.  Gotta love them anyway. :P

So much has happened since my old blog died, I don't know where to begin.  Rather than go into lengthy explanations, how about I just forget about the past month and start fresh.

Tonight, Ryan and I went with the entire family (grandma, papa, Aunt Barbara, the works) out to dinner at a nearby restaurant that the family loves.  The hostess, is a family friend.  Well, tonight, she asked me if I was pregnant.  I about died!  I'm not pregnant so naturally, I freaked out.  I said no, I'm just fat.  In all reality, I'm not fat.  I weigh only 126 pounds and I stand 5'4" so I am perfectly proportioned but I am very sensitive about my weight.  You see, when I moved to Canada to be with my husband, it was the holiday season and we ate out and large meals a LOT.  What happened was that I gained a good 15 pounds.  I lost 5 pounds so far but I still feel like I am weighing more than I should.  So what does any red-blooded female do when asked if they are pregnant when they aren't?  I ran to the bathroom and cried like a baby.  So there you have it!  My night in a nutshell.  Great day, eh?
To be brief, the old blog died and I'm using this now.  Simple enough. :P
